Additional information factors contained Company&#146;s Securities Exchange Commission filings, including 2009 Form 10-K. </DIV> <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-11-<!-- /Folio --> </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table Contents</A></H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"> <DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><U><B>Overview</B></U> </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company recorded net income $129&nbsp;million quarter 2010 compared net loss $377&nbsp;million period year. The Company&#146;s improved performance primarily result higher unit revenues (passenger revenue seat mile). Mainline passenger unit revenues increased 10.7&nbsp;percent quarter due 10.7&nbsp;percent increase passenger yield (passenger revenue passenger mile) stable load factor compared period 2009. Although passenger yield showed year-over-year improvement, passenger yield remains levels set 2000 cumulative inflation 30&nbsp;percent time frame. The Company believes result fragmented industry numerous competitors, excess capacity pricing transparency resulting Internet factors. The Company believes limited pricing power persist indefinitely. </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The increases comparative quarter revenue partially offset significant year-over-year increase fuel prices average $2.06 gallon quarter 2009 average $2.24 gallon quarter 2010, including effects hedging. The price increase resulted $110&nbsp;million incremental year-over-year fuel expense months ended September&nbsp;30, 2010 (based year-over-year increase average price gallon multiplied gallons consumed). </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In late 2009, Company unveiled business plan &#151; FlightPlan 2020. FlightPlan 2020 strategic framework developed secure Company&#146;s future focusing required succeed airline business decade. It establishes Company&#146;s priorities clear path position Company meet challenges coming years. This plan achieving sustained profitability tenets: (i)&nbsp;Invest Wisely, (ii)&nbsp;Earn Customer Loyalty, (iii)&nbsp;Strengthen Defend Global Network, (iv)&nbsp;Be Good Place Good People (v)&nbsp;Fly Profitably. </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Under FlightPlan 2020, Company launched network strategy focuses resources cornerstone markets Dallas/Fort Worth, Chicago, Miami, Los Angeles New York, continued execute fleet renewal replacement plan. Further, Company continues pursue strategy form cooperative agreements <B>one</B>world members airlines. In July 2010, American obtained clearance European Commission (EC)&nbsp;and approval Department Transportation (DOT)&nbsp;for antitrust immunity (ATI)&nbsp;for planned cooperation British Airways, Iberia, Finnair Royal Jordanian. In addition, Company awaiting final approval regulatory entities American&#146;s joint business agreement (JBA)&nbsp;with Airlines (JAL). </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Regulatory conditions ATI approval British Airways, Iberia, Finnair Royal Jordanian cooperative agreement include obligations lease carriers takeoff landing slot pairs London Heathrow John F. Kennedy airport operational authorities, depending market conditions. American began implementation JBA British Airways Iberia expanded cooperation Finnair Royal Jordanian October 2010. No assurances arrangements ultimately implemented benefits Company derive arrangements. </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In conjunction initiation JBA British Airways Iberia, American announced sending recall notices 545 furloughed flight attendants 250 furloughed pilots. Several factors contributed Company&#146;s ability recall employees, primarily efforts capitalize international flying business opportunities JBA British Airways Iberia, continuing strengthen presence cornerstone markets, preparing anticipated JBA JAL. </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On October&nbsp;6, 2010, issued order tentatively approving joint application filed American JAL ATI routes North America Asia. Implementation JBA JAL pending final approval joint notification Ministry Land Infrastructure, Transport Tourism (MLIT). Implementation subject successful negotiation detailed financial commercial arrangements approvals. American expects begin implementing JBA JAL 2011. No assurances arrangements ultimately implemented benefits Company derive arrangements. </DIV> <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-12-<!-- /Folio --> </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table Contents</A></H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s previously announced commercial collaboration New York Boston JetBlue commenced July 2010. American&#146;s agreement JetBlue customers interline service non-overlapping markets, letting customers connect 14 American&#146;s international destinations New York Boston 18 domestic cities flown JetBlue. Further, American announced expand relationship JetBlue AAdvantage members members JetBlue&#146;s customer loyalty program earn AAdvantage miles JetBlue points, respectively, fly American JetBlue cooperative interline routes. Under terms agreements commercial collaboration, American intends transfer slot pairs Ronald Reagan National Airport Washington D.C. (currently owned American) slot pair White Plains, New York (currently owned AMR Eagle) JetBlue, JetBlue intends transfer twelve slot pairs JFK American; reciprocal frequent flyer earning benefits slot transfers scheduled fourth quarter 2010. </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also July 2010, Company announced plans extend network commercial collaboration Germany&#146;s second-largest airline, Air Berlin. The agreement American Air Berlin initiates comprehensive interline codeshare frequent flyer relationship customers airline book travel other&#146;s network earn frequent flyer miles. American Air Berlin expect implement codeshare regulatory approval. In event investigations uncover violations U.S. antitrust laws competition laws jurisdiction, findings related legal proceedings material adverse impact Company. Approximately 52 purported class action lawsuits filed U.S. Company foreign domestic air carriers alleging defendants violated U.S. antitrust laws illegally conspiring set prices surcharges passenger transportation. On October&nbsp;25, 2006, cases, purported class action lawsuits Company named, consolidated United States District Court Northern District California <U>In International Air Transportation Surcharge Antitrust Litigation</U>, Civ. No.&nbsp;06-1793 (the Passenger MDL). On July&nbsp;9, 2007, Company named defendant Passenger MDL. On August&nbsp;25, 2008, plaintiffs dismissed claims Company action. On March&nbsp;13, 2008, March&nbsp;14, 2008, additional purported class action complaint, Turner v. American Airlines, al., Civ. No.&nbsp;08-1444 (N.D. Cal.), filed Company, alleging Company violated U.S. antitrust laws illegally conspiring set prices surcharges passenger transportation European countries, respectively. The Turner plaintiffs failed perfect service Company, unclear intend pursue claims. In event Turner plaintiffs pursue claims, Company vigorously defend lawsuits, adverse judgment actions material adverse impact Company. </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On August&nbsp;21, 2006, patent infringement lawsuit filed American American Beacon Advisors, Inc. (then wholly-owned subsidiary Company) United States District Court Eastern District Texas (<U>Ronald A. Katz Technology Licensing, L.P. v. American Airlines, Inc., al.</U>). This case consolidated Central District California pre-trial purposes numerous cases brought plaintiff defendants. The plaintiff alleges American infringes number plaintiff&#146;s patents, relates automated telephone call processing systems. The plaintiff seeking past future royalties, injunctive relief, costs attorneys&#146; fees. On December&nbsp;1, 2008, court dismissed prejudice claims American Beacon. On May&nbsp;22, 2009, granting summary judgment American based invalidity non-infringement, court dismissed claims American. Plaintiff filed notice appeal June&nbsp;22, 2009 respect court&#146;s ruling American. Although Company believes plaintiff&#146;s claims merit vigorously defending lawsuit, final adverse court decision awarding substantial money damages placing material restrictions existing automated telephone call system operations material adverse impact Company. </DIV> <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-24-<!-- /Folio --> </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table Contents</A></H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"> <DIV align="left"> <A name="112"></A> </DIV> <DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Item&nbsp;6</B></U><B>. </B><U><B>Exhibits </B></U> </DIV> <DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Exhibits required filed Item&nbsp;601 Regulation&nbsp;S-K. <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"> <DIV align="right" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Exhibit&nbsp;31.1</B> </DIV> <DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">I, Gerard J. Pursuant amendment, American exercised rights purchase 35 Boeing 737-800 aircraft delivery 2011 2012. In conjunction transaction, American arranged backstop financing additional Boeing 737-800 aircraft deliveries, subject terms conditions. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;As September&amp;#160;30, 2010, American twelve Boeing 737-800 aircraft purchase commitments remainder 2010 43 Boeing 737-800 aircraft purchase commitments 2011 2012. In addition aircraft purchase commitments, American firm purchase commitments eleven Boeing 737-800 aircraft Boeing 777 aircraft scheduled delivered 2013 2016. American previously announced plans (subject reconfirmation rights) acquire 42 Boeing 787-9 aircraft, acquire additional 58 Boeing 787-9 aircraft. &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;The Company required make minimum contributions defined benefit pension plans minimum funding requirements Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), Pension Funding Equity Act 2004 Pension Protection Act 2006. In June 2010, President Obama signed Preservation Access Care Medical Beneficiaries Pension Relief Act 2010 (the Relief Act), H.R. 3962, law. The Relief Act temporary, targeted funding relief (subject terms conditions) single employer multiemployer pension plans suffered significant losses asset due steep market slide 2008. Under Relief Act, Company&amp;#8217;s 2010 minimum required contribution defined benefit pension plans reduced $525&amp;#160;million approximately $460&amp;#160;million, completed date filing. The Company estimates 2011 minimum required contribution defined benefit pension plans approximately $520 million. This estimate subject change based final plan asset values December&amp;#160;31, 2010. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;/div&gt; </us-gaap:PensionAndOtherPostretirementBenefitsDisclosureTextBlock> <!-- End Block Tagged Note --> <!-- Begin Block Tagged Note --> <us-gaap:RestructuringAndRelatedActivitiesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="January-01-2010_September-30-2010">&lt;!--DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd" --&gt; &lt;!-- Begin Block Tagged Note 8 - us-gaap:RestructuringAndRelatedActivitiesDisclosureTextBlock--&gt; &lt;div style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;8. &lt;div style="display: none"&gt;Restructuring And Related Activities Disclosure &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;As result revenue environment, high fuel prices Company&amp;#8217;s restructuring activities, including capacity reductions, Company recorded number charges years. &lt;!-- Begin Block Tagged Note 9 - us-gaap:DerivativeInstrumentsAndHedgingActivitiesDisclosureTextBlock--&gt; &lt;div style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;9. &lt;div style="display: none"&gt;Derivative Instruments And Hedging Activities Disclosure &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;As part Company&amp;#8217;s risk management program, variety financial instruments, heating oil collar contracts, cash flow hedges mitigate commodity price risk. The Company hold issue derivative financial instruments trading purposes. As September&amp;#160;30, 2010, Company fuel derivative contracts outstanding covering 31&amp;#160;million barrels jet fuel settled 24&amp;#160;months. A deterioration Company&amp;#8217;s liquidity position negatively affect Company&amp;#8217;s ability hedge fuel future. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;For months ended September&amp;#160;30, 2010, Company recognized increase approximately $20&amp;#160;million $123&amp;#160;million, respectively, fuel expense accompanying consolidated statements operations related fuel hedging agreements, including ineffective portion hedges. For months ended September&amp;#160;30, 2009, Company recognized increase approximately $96&amp;#160;million $518&amp;#160;million, respectively, fuel expense related fuel hedging agreements including ineffective portion hedges. The net fair Company&amp;#8217;s fuel hedging agreements September&amp;#160;30, 2010 December&amp;#160;31, 2009, representing amount Company receive termination agreements (net settled contract assets), totaled $125&amp;#160;million $57&amp;#160;million, respectively, excludes payable related contracts settled month respective reporting period. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; PAGEBREAK --&gt; &lt;div style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"&gt; &lt;div align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt"&gt; &lt;b&gt; &lt;/b&gt; &lt;u&gt; &lt;/u&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;The Company required make minimum contributions defined benefit pension plans minimum funding requirements Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), Pension Funding Equity Act 2004 Pension Protection Act 2006. In June 2010, President Obama signed Preservation Access Care Medical Beneficiaries Pension Relief Act 2010 (the Relief Act), H.R. 3962, law. The Relief Act temporary, targeted funding relief (subject terms conditions) single employer multiemployer pension plans suffered significant losses asset due steep market slide 2008. Under Relief Act, Company&amp;#8217;s 2010 minimum required contribution defined benefit pension plans reduced $525&amp;#160;million approximately $460&amp;#160;million, completed date filing. The Company estimates 2011 minimum required contribution defined benefit pension plans approximately $520 million. This estimate subject change based final plan asset values December&amp;#160;31, 2010. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;/div&gt; The Company&amp;#8217;s policy recording transfers levels record transfers end reporting period. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;In January&amp;#160;2010, Venezuelan Government devalued currency 2.15 bolivars U.S. dollar 4.30 bolivars U.S. dollar Venezuelan economy designated highly inflationary. As result, Company recognized loss $53&amp;#160;million related currency remeasurement January&amp;#160;2010. The Company expect significant ongoing impact currency devaluation system-wide operations. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;The fair values Company&amp;#8217;s long-term debt estimated quoted market prices available. &lt;!-- Begin Block Tagged Note</NonNumericTextHeader> <FootnoteIndexer /> <hasSegments>false</hasSegments> <hasScenarios>false</hasScenarios> <DisplayDateInUSFormat>false</DisplayDateInUSFormat> </Cell> </Cells> <OriginalInstanceReportColumns /> <ElementDataType>us-types:textBlockItemType</ElementDataType> <SimpleDataType>textblock</SimpleDataType> <ElementDefenition>This item represents complete disclosure fair financial instruments (as defined), including financial assets financial liabilities (collectively, defined), measurements instruments, assets, liabilities. Such disclosures financial instruments, assets, liabilities include: (1) fair required items carrying amounts (as appropriate); (2) items practicable estimate fair value, disclosure include: (a) information pertinent estimating fair (including, carrying amount, effective interest rate, maturity, (b) reasons practicable estimate fair value; (3) significant concentrations credit risk including: (a) information activity, region, economic characteristics identifying concentration, (b) maximum amount loss Company exposed based gross fair related item, (c) policy requiring collateral security information accessing collateral security, (d) nature description collateral security; (4) quantitative information market risks risk managed; (5) items measured recurring nonrecurring basis information inputs develop fair measurement; (6) items presented financial statement fair measurement elected: (a) information understand reasons election, (b) discussion effect fair earnings, (c) description [similar groups] items election made relation thereof balance sheet, aggregate carrying items included balance sheet eligible election; (7) required (as defined) desired information.</ElementDefenition> <ElementReferences>Reference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 107 The Company&amp;#8217;s deferred tax asset valuation allowance increased approximately $53&amp;#160;million months ended September&amp;#160;30, 2010 $3.6&amp;#160;billion September&amp;#160;30, 2010, including impact comprehensive income months ended September&amp;#160;30, 2010 adjustments. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;Under current accounting rules, Company required items (including items recorded comprehensive income) determining amount tax benefit results loss continuing operations allocated continuing operations. <ElementDataType>xbrli:monetaryItemType</ElementDataType> <SimpleDataType>monetary</SimpleDataType> <ElementDefenition>Includes currency hand demand deposits banks financial institutions. It includes kinds accounts general characteristics demand deposits Entity deposit additional funds time effectively withdraw funds time prior notice penalty. Cash equivalents, excluding items classified marketable securities, include short-term, highly liquid investments readily convertible amounts cash, maturity present minimal risk interest rates. Generally, investments original maturities months qualify definition. Original maturity means original maturity entity holding investment. For example, three-month US Treasury bill three-year Treasury note purchased months maturity qualify cash equivalents. However, Treasury note purchased ree years ago cash equivalent remaining maturity months. Compensating balance arrangements legally restrict withdrawal usage cash amounts reported Cash Cash Equivalents, legally restricted deposits held compensating balances borrowing arrangements, contracts entered others, company statements intention regard deposits reported cash cash equivalents.</ElementDefenition> <ElementReferences>Reference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef <OriginalInstanceReportColumns /> <ElementDataType>xbrli:monetaryItemType</ElementDataType> <SimpleDataType>monetary</SimpleDataType> <ElementDefenition>Includes currency hand demand deposits banks financial institutions. It includes kinds accounts general characteristics demand deposits Entity deposit additional funds time effectively withdraw funds time prior notice penalty. Cash equivalents, excluding items classified marketable securities, include short-term, highly liquid investments readily convertible amounts cash, maturity present minimal risk interest rates. Generally, investments original maturities months qualify definition. Original maturity means original maturity entity holding investment. For example, three-month US Treasury bill three-year Treasury note purchased months maturity qualify cash equivalents. However, Treasury note purchased ree years ago cash equivalent remaining maturity months. &lt;!-- Begin Block Tagged Note 5 - us-gaap:ScheduleOfGuaranteeObligationsTextBlock--&gt; &lt;div style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;5. &lt;div style="display: none"&gt;Schedule Of Guarantee Obligations &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;As September&amp;#160;30, 2010, American issued guarantees covering approximately $887&amp;#160;million AMR&amp;#8217;s unsecured debt (and interest thereon). In addition, September&amp;#160;30, 2010, AMR American issued guarantees covering approximately $216&amp;#160;million AMR Eagle&amp;#8217;s secured debt (and interest thereon). &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;/div&gt; </NonNumbericText> <NonNumericTextHeader>&lt;!--DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd" --&gt; &lt;!-- Begin Block Tagged Note</NonNumericTextHeader> <FootnoteIndexer /> <hasSegments>false</hasSegments> <hasScenarios>false</hasScenarios> <DisplayDateInUSFormat>false</DisplayDateInUSFormat> </Cell> </Cells> <OriginalInstanceReportColumns /> <ElementDataType>us-types:textBlockItemType</ElementDataType> <SimpleDataType>textblock</SimpleDataType> <ElementDefenition>Provides pertinent information guarantee obligation, group similar guarantee obligations, including (a) nature guarantee, including term, arose, events circumstances require guarantor perform guarantee; (b) maximum potential amount future payments (undiscounted) guarantor required make guarantee; (c) current carrying amount liability, any, guarantor's obligations guarantee; (d) nature recourse provisions guarantee, assets held collateral parties, relevant related party disclosure. 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;9. &lt;div style="display: none"&gt;Derivative Instruments And Hedging Activities Disclosure &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;As part Company&amp;#8217;s risk management program, variety financial instruments, heating oil collar contracts, cash flow hedges mitigate commodity price risk. The Company hold issue derivative financial instruments trading purposes. As September&amp;#160;30, 2010, Company fuel derivative contracts outstanding covering 31&amp;#160;million barrels jet fuel settled 24&amp;#160;months. A deterioration Company&amp;#8217;s liquidity position negatively affect Company&amp;#8217;s ability hedge fuel future. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="margin-top: 6pt"&gt; &lt;table width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt; &lt;tr valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"&gt; &lt;td width="1%" nowrap="nowrap" align="left"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td&gt; &lt;div align="justify"&gt;For months ended September&amp;#160;30, 2010, Company recognized increase approximately $20&amp;#160;million $123&amp;#160;million, respectively, fuel expense accompanying consolidated statements operations related fuel hedging agreements, including ineffective portion hedges. For months ended September&amp;#160;30, 2009, Company recognized increase approximately $96&amp;#160;million $518&amp;#160;million, respectively, fuel expense related fuel hedging agreements including ineffective portion hedges. The net fair Company&amp;#8217;s fuel hedging agreements September&amp;#160;30, 2010 December&amp;#160;31, 2009, representing amount Company receive termination agreements (net settled contract assets), totaled $125&amp;#160;million $57&amp;#160;million, respectively, excludes payable related contracts settled month respective reporting period. &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
